compounds.local_name: メトキシメタン（ジメチルエーテル）
compounds.series_general_formula: Simple ethers: CnH2n+2O (same as monohydric alcohols)
compounds.notes: Simplest ether; structural isomer of ethanol; typical example in questions on isomerism and boiling-point comparison with alcohols.

compounds.local_name: エトキシエタン（ジエチルエーテル）
compounds.notes: Representative ether produced by intermolecular dehydration of ethanol; volatile, flammable solvent; appears in many textbook examples.

compounds.local_name: メトキシエタン（メチルエチルエーテル）
compounds.notes: Unsymmetrical ether; good for practice of IUPAC naming and for isomerism problems with C3H8O alcohols (propanols).

compounds.local_name: エタンド-1,2-ジオール（エチレングリコール）
compounds.notes: Dihydric alcohol; used as antifreeze and in polyester production; typical example of 2-valent alcohol.

compounds.local_name: プロパン-1,2-ジオール（プロピレングリコール）
compounds.notes: Dihydric alcohol; used as solvent and humectant; often contrasted with more toxic ethylene glycol.

compounds.local_name: プロパン-1,2,3-トリオール（グリセリン）
compounds.notes: Trihydric alcohol; viscous, sweet-tasting liquid; important in fats, soaps, and many biomolecules; typical 3-valent alcohol in exams.
Simplest aliphatic alcohol; toxic; used as industrial solvent and fuel; often compared with ethanol in exams.
Typical primary alcohol; produced by fermentation; oxidized to ethanal then ethanoic acid; starting material for diethyl ether and ethene via dehydration.
Straight-chain C3 primary alcohol; used as example of homologous series extension from ethanol.
Representative higher primary alcohol; often appears as example in classification tables (消防法区分などとともに).

compounds.local_name: 2-メチルプロパン-1-オール（イソブチルアルコール）
compounds.notes: Branched primary alcohol; useful for questions comparing boiling points and reactivity of isomeric alcohols.

compounds.local_name: 2-メチルプロパン-2-オール（tert-ブチルアルコール）
compounds.notes: Prototypical tertiary alcohol; OH-bearing carbon is attached to three other carbons; resists oxidation under conditions where primary and secondary alcohols oxidize.

compounds.local_name: 2-メチルブタン-2-オール（tert-アミルアルコール）
compounds.notes: Tertiary alcohol with five carbons; useful for advanced naming and classification, showing branching and tertiary carbon.

compounds.local_name: 2-プロパノール（イソプロピルアルコール）
compounds.notes: Typical secondary alcohol; used as disinfectant and solvent; gives a ketone (propanone) on oxidation and positive iodoform test.

compounds.local_name: 2-ブタノール（セカンダリーブタノール）
compounds.notes: Representative secondary alcohol in many Japanese explanations of classification; oxidized to butan-2-one (a ketone).
Example of secondary alcohol where the OH-bearing carbon is in the middle of a longer chain; useful for naming and classification exercises.

compounds.local_name: メタナミド（ホルムアミド）
compounds.series_general_formula: Primary amides from monocarboxylic acids: RCONH2 (n>=0, n=0 gives formamide)
compounds.notes: Simplest carboxylic acid amide; highly polar; used as solvent and intermediate; typical example when introducing the amide functional group.

compounds.local_name: エタナミド（アセトアミド）
compounds.series_general_formula: Primary amides from saturated monocarboxylic acids: CnH2n+1CONH2
compounds.notes: Most commonly discussed aliphatic amide; derived from ethanoic acid; used as example of high melting point and hydrogen bonding in amides.

compounds.series_general_formula: Primary amides from saturated monocarboxylic acids: CnH2n+1CONH2
compounds.notes: Higher member of the aliphatic amide series; useful for homologous-series questions and for comparing physical properties with ethanamide.

compounds.series_general_formula: Diamides (carbamides): general structure H2N-CO-NH2 or substituted analogs
compounds.notes: Most important biological amide; end product of protein metabolism in mammals; typical example of a diamide in high-school chemistry.

compounds.local_name: メタンアミン（メチルアミン）
compounds.notes: Simplest primary aliphatic amine; gas with ammonia-like smell; basic; typical example in tests distinguishing primary, secondary and tertiary amines.

compounds.local_name: エタンアミン（エチルアミン）
compounds.notes: Typical lower primary amine; basic and water-soluble; smells like ammonia; standard example in many exam problems.

compounds.local_name: プロパン-1-アミン（n-プロピルアミン）
compounds.notes: Higher primary amine; used for homologous series questions and comparison of basicity and solubility trends.
Simple secondary amine; used to illustrate classification (primary vs secondary vs tertiary) and differences in reactivity with nitrous acid.
Typical tertiary amine; has strong fishy smell; appears in questions about classification, basicity, and solubility of amines.

compounds.series_general_formula: Primary nitroalkanes: RNO2 (R = alkyl), simplest CnH2n+1NO2
compounds.notes: Simplest nitroalkane; used as solvent and in fuels; classic example of a nitro compound in high-school texts.
Primary nitroalkane; used industrially as solvent and intermediate; typical example in classification of nitro compounds.
Primary nitroalkane; appears together with 2-nitropropane in questions that compare primary and secondary nitro compounds.
Secondary nitroalkane; contrasted with 1-nitropropane in reactivity and physical properties; used as solvent and intermediate.

compounds.local_name: メタナール（ホルムアルデヒド）
compounds.notes: Simplest aldehyde; gas at room temperature, used as aqueous solution (formalin) as a disinfectant and preservative; gives positive silver mirror and Fehling's tests.

compounds.local_name: エタナール（アセトアルデヒド）
compounds.notes: Produced by mild oxidation of ethanol; gives positive silver mirror and Fehling's tests; also positive iodoform test because it contains the CH3-CHO group.

compounds.local_name: プロパナール（プロピオンアルデヒド）
compounds.notes: Straight-chain C3 aldehyde; typical member of the homologous series used to illustrate boiling point trends and general formula CnH2nO.

compounds.local_name: ブタナール（酪酸アルデヒド）
compounds.notes: C4 aldehyde; often appears in homologous-series tables alongside methanal, ethanal and propanal; shows typical aldehyde reactions (oxidation to carboxylic acid).

compounds.local_name: 2-メチルプロパナール（イソ酪酸アルデヒド）
compounds.notes: Branched C4 aldehyde; useful for problems on structural isomerism and naming of branched-chain aldehydes.

functional_groups.name_ja: ケトン基（カルボニル基）

compounds.notes: Simplest ketone; very common solvent; classic example of a methyl ketone that gives a positive iodoform test (R-CO-CH3).

compounds.local_name: ブタノン（メチルエチルケトン）

functional_groups.name_ja: ケトン基（カルボニル基）

compounds.notes: Typical C4 ketone; used industrially as solvent; another methyl ketone giving a positive iodoform test; often paired with propanone in exam questions.

compounds.local_name: ペンタン-2-オン（メチルプロピルケトン）

functional_groups.name_ja: ケトン基（カルボニル基）

compounds.notes: Higher methyl ketone; good for practicing naming, homologous-series relations, and comparing physical properties with shorter ketones.

functional_groups.name_ja: ケトン基（カルボニル基）

compounds.notes: Symmetrical C5 ketone; contrasted with pentan-2-one in isomerism questions and in reactivity of methyl ketones (iodoform test: negative for pentan-3-one).

compounds.series_general_formula: Saturated monocarboxylic acids: CnH2n+1COOH (n>=0, n=0 gives HCOOH)
compounds.notes: Simplest carboxylic acid; present in ant stings; stronger than acetic acid; can act both as a reducing agent and an acid.
Main acid in vinegar; typical monobasic carboxylic acid; used to define many esterification examples such as ethyl ethanoate.

compounds.local_name: プロパン酸（プロピオン酸）
compounds.notes: Third member of the saturated monocarboxylic acid series; used as preservative; standard example in homologous-series problems.
Has strong rancid-butter odor; often used as example for characteristic smells of carboxylic acids and their esters.

compounds.series_general_formula: Saturated dicarboxylic acids: HOOC-(CH2)n-COOH (n>=0, n=0 gives oxalic acid)
compounds.notes: Simplest dicarboxylic acid; found in rhubarb and spinach; typical example of dibasic carboxylic acid in high-school texts.

compounds.local_name: メチルメタン酸メチル（メチルギ酸メチル）
compounds.series_general_formula: Simple saturated esters: general molecular formula CnH2nO2, structure R-COOR'
compounds.notes: Simplest aliphatic ester; used as solvent and flavoring; typical example in basic esterification reactions.

compounds.local_name: メチルエタン酸メチル（酢酸メチル）
compounds.series_general_formula: Simple saturated esters: CnH2nO2 (from monocarboxylic acids and alcohols)
compounds.notes: Low-boiling ester with fruity smell; often used as example in problems comparing boiling points of acids, esters and alcohols.

compounds.local_name: エチルエタン酸エチル（酢酸エチル）
compounds.series_general_formula: Simple saturated esters: CnH2nO2, structure R-COO-R'
compounds.notes: Very common solvent; prepared by esterification of ethanol and ethanoic acid; standard example for ester smell and hydrolysis.

compounds.local_name: プロピルエタン酸プロピル（酢酸プロピル）
compounds.notes: Fruity-smelling ester; used to exemplify how changing the alcohol changes the odor while keeping the same acid part.

compounds.local_name: メチルブタン酸メチル（酪酸メチル）
compounds.notes: Has pineapple-like fruity odor; common example in questions relating smell to ester structure derived from butanoic acid.
Simplest alkane; main component of natural gas; typical saturated hydrocarbon showing substitution and combustion reactions.
Straight-chain alkane; gas at room temperature; used as a component of natural gas and as a feedstock for ethene.
Fuel gas; major component of liquefied petroleum gas (LPG); standard example of combustion and substitution reactions.
Straight-chain isomer of C4H10; used as fuel gas; contrasted with isobutane (2-methylpropane) in isomer questions.

compounds.local_name: 2-メチルプロパン（イソブタン）
compounds.notes: Branched-chain isomer of butane; important example of structural isomerism; used as refrigerant and propellant.
Straight-chain C5 alkane; typical example when studying multiple structural isomers (n-pentane, isopentane, neopentane).

compounds.local_name: 2-メチルブタン（イソペンタン）
compounds.notes: Branched C5 alkane; classic example of structural isomerism and boiling point comparison among C5H12 isomers.

compounds.local_name: 2,2-ジメチルプロパン（ネオペンタン）
compounds.notes: Most highly branched C5H12 isomer; very low boiling point; emphasized in problems on branching vs boiling point.
Straight-chain C6 alkane; common non-polar solvent; basis for many C6 isomer questions.
Straight-chain C7 alkane; appears in questions on boiling points and combustion.
Straight-chain C8 alkane; octane number in gasoline quality is defined using its isomers (notably 2,2,4-trimethylpentane).
Simplest alkene; industrially very important; basis for polyethylene via addition polymerization.
Typical terminal alkene; starting material for polypropylene and many addition reactions.
Terminal C4 alkene; used to illustrate position isomerism with but-2-ene in textbooks.
Internal C4 alkene; example of position isomerism with but-1-ene and of cis–trans (E/Z) isomerism.

compounds.local_name: 2-メチルプロペン（イソブテン）
compounds.notes: Highly substituted alkene; used industrially to make polyisobutene and MTBE; good example of Markovnikov addition.
Representative higher terminal alkene; used in problems on general formula CnH2n and homologous series.
Conjugated diene; important monomer for synthetic rubber (e.g. polybutadiene, styrene-butadiene rubber).
Simplest alkyne; strong reducing agent; used in oxyacetylene welding and as a starting material for many syntheses.

compounds.local_name: プロピン（メチルアセチレン）
compounds.notes: Simplest terminal C3 alkyne; used to illustrate substitution vs addition on terminal alkynes.
Terminal C4 alkyne; appears in problems on general formula CnH2n-2 and position isomerism with but-2-yne.
Internal C4 alkyne; contrasts with but-1-yne in acidity of terminal hydrogen and in some reaction patterns.
Smallest cycloalkane; large ring strain and relatively reactive; used as example of angle strain.
Four-membered cycloalkane; still strained and more reactive than larger rings.
Relatively low ring strain; together with cyclohexane, used as example of stable cycloalkanes in textbooks.
Most stable cycloalkane; adopts chair conformation with minimal strain; key example for conformational analysis.
